sections.title: Welcome to FRC Programming
sections.content: Welcome to the comprehensive FRC (FIRST Robotics Competition) programming curriculum! This curriculum is designed to take you from complete beginner to advanced FRC programmer, covering WPILib framework, command-based programming, control theory, and professional robotics development practices.

sections.title: What is FRC?
sections.subtitle: FIRST Robotics Competition is:
items: A robotics competition for high school students (grades 9-12)
A platform for learning professional engineering and programming practices
An opportunity to work with industrial-grade robotics hardware and software
A chance to develop advanced problem-solving and teamwork skills
A pathway to careers in engineering, programming, and STEM fields
A competition that combines strategy, design, and programming excellence

sections.title: Curriculum Structure
sections.content: This FRC curriculum is organized into comprehensive learning modules, each building essential skills for competitive robotics:

sections.title: Learning Modules
items: Environment Setup: Master WPILib installation, project creation, VS Code setup, Gradle build system, Driver Station configuration, and SmartDashboard usage. Essential foundation for all FRC development.
Hardware Vendors: Learn to work with CTRE (Talon FX, CANcoder) and REV (Spark MAX, Spark) motor controllers, sensors, and pneumatics. Understand configuration, PID control, and advanced features.
Command-Based Programming: Master the command-based framework with subsystems, commands, command groups, triggers, and the robot container pattern. Professional architecture for complex robots.
Control Theory: Deep dive into PID control, motion profiling (trapezoidal and exponential), feedforward control, and advanced control techniques. Essential for precise robot movement.
Pose Estimation: Learn odometry basics, swerve odometry, vision-based pose estimation, AprilTag integration, sensor fusion, and tuning techniques for accurate robot localization.
Path Planning: Master PathPlanner setup, trajectory creation, path following, event markers, AutoBuilder, and tuning. Create sophisticated autonomous routines.
YAMS Framework: Learn the YAMS (Yet Another Mechanism System) framework for mechanism configuration, state machines, commands, and advanced patterns.
Advanced Topics: Explore AdvantageScope logging and analysis, AdvantageKit architecture, simulation basics and advanced simulation, unit testing, and professional code organization.

sections.title: Learning Path Overview
sections.content: Follow this recommended learning path to build your FRC programming skills systematically:

items: Start with Environment Setup: Begin with WPILib setup and project creation. Learn VS Code configuration, understand the Gradle build system, and set up Driver Station and SmartDashboard.
Master Hardware Integration: Learn to configure and control motors using CTRE and REV hardware. Understand encoders, sensors, PID control, and current limiting.
Learn Command-Based Architecture: Understand subsystems, commands, and the command scheduler. Build well-structured, maintainable robot code.
Implement Control Systems: Master PID control, motion profiling, and feedforward control. Create smooth, precise robot movements.
Add Pose Estimation: Implement odometry and vision-based localization. Enable sophisticated autonomous behaviors.
Create Autonomous Paths: Use PathPlanner to design and execute complex autonomous routines with events and markers.
Explore Advanced Tools: Learn AdvantageScope for data analysis, AdvantageKit for advanced architecture, and simulation for testing.

sections.title: Prerequisites
sections.subtitle: Before starting FRC programming, you should have:
items: Solid understanding of Java programming fundamentals
Familiarity with object-oriented programming concepts
Understanding of basic electronics and robotics hardware
Access to FRC robot hardware (or simulation environment)
WPILib development environment set up
Willingness to learn professional software development practices
WPILib: Official FRC programming framework with libraries, tools, and utilities
VS Code: Recommended IDE with WPILib extensions for FRC development
Gradle: Build system used by WPILib projects for dependency management
Driver Station: Software for controlling and monitoring robots during competition
SmartDashboard: Real-time robot data visualization and control interface
PathPlanner: Visual path planning tool for autonomous routines
AdvantageScope: Data logging and analysis tool for robot performance
AdvantageKit: Advanced framework for professional FRC development

sections.title: Best Practices
sections.content: Follow these practices for professional FRC development:

items: Use Command-Based Architecture: Organize code with subsystems and commands for maintainability
Version Control: Use Git to track changes and collaborate with your team
Test Thoroughly: Test code in simulation and on practice robots before competition
Document Code: Write clear comments and documentation for team members
Follow WPILib Conventions: Use standard naming and structure patterns
Log Data: Use AdvantageScope to analyze robot performance and debug issues
Plan Autonomous: Design autonomous routines with PathPlanner before coding
Code Reviews: Have team members review code for quality and correctness

sections.title: Getting Started
sections.content: Ready to begin your FRC programming journey? Start with the WPILib Setup lesson in the Environment Setup section to learn the fundamentals of FRC development.

sections.title: FRC Programming Readiness
sections.description: Before starting FRC programming, assess your readiness:
tasks: Do you have access to FRC robot hardware or simulation tools?
Are you comfortable with Java programming and object-oriented concepts?
Have you set up the WPILib development environment?
How much time can you dedicate to learning and practice?
What are your goals (competition, learning, career development)?
Are you comfortable working with industrial-grade hardware?
Do you have a team or mentor to work with?
Are you ready to learn professional software development practices?
